H0.text: Draining a springâ€‘fed pond would most likely cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

H1.text: Plowing and planting meadows is most likely to cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

H2.text: Destroying all dead trees and stumps would most likely cause a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

H3.text: Building a road around a small forest is the most likely cause of a decrease in the number of woodpeckers in an ecosystem.

A4.text: deadwood is an important habitat requirement for the black woodpecker, great spotted woodpecker, middle spotted woodpecker, lesser spotted woodpecker, European green woodpecker, and Eurasian three-toed woodpecker.

A5.text: forest-dwelling species need rotting or dead wood on which to forage.

A6.text: Even the simplest forms of agriculture affect diversity through clearing or draining the land.

A7.text: It is observed from the worlds longest running fragmentation experiment over 35 years that habitat fragmentation has caused a decrease in biodiversity from 13% to 75%.

A10.text: human activities, invasive species, and climate change could initiate long-term changes in wetland ecosystems.

A11.text: Most natural ecosystems experience disturbance at a rate that makes a 'climax' community unattainable.
